answers.text:
Hi Jacob, 
Here is a similar instance of voters voting for a tax and the elected officials and city manager feeling grateful for the community understanding the situation and supporting them. Although this article does not say how the government thanked the citizens it does say the citizens were happy with the tax knowing exactly how is will be used so providing that type of information to your citizens would likely be appropriate and something they would appreciate. As long as it does not violate the code of ethics I think you could publicly thank the voters if you feel it is appropriate.
-Example of taxes being passed https://webapps.icma.org/pm/8509/kellar.htm
-Here is the ICMA Code of Ethics with accompanying guidelines in case you would like to brush up on it before making your decision. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/100265/ICMA_Code_of_Ethics_with_Guidelines
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern 
rsaywitz@icma.org

author: Jacob Foos
text: After the passing of a local sales tax that supports Fire, EMS and Parks and Recreation services, is it appropriate to publicly thank the voters and highlight the services that the funds will contribute to?  Any input is appreciated.  Thank you.
title: Thanking Voters?
